properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for this afternoon. The snow squall watch has been changed to a winter weather travel advisory. Lake effect snow bands are expected to move into the area this afternoon affecting communities north of highway 22 including Parkhill. Travel may be impacted due to accumulating snow and low visibility in heavy snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T07:19:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T15:53:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3657161446.2019
Area: Strathroy - Komoka - Western Middlesex County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls today through Wednesday morning. Flurries and local snow squalls continue and are expected to persist into Wednesday morning. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible today and amounts of near 15 cm are possible tonight into Wednesday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero will also be a concern. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to southwest Wednesday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T05:22:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T13:23:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3598033305.2019
Area: Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Approaching storm will give mixed precipitation today into Wednesday morning. Rain over the Islands is expected to become intermittent this afternoon, then redevelop tonight and continue into Wednesday morning. Total accumulations of 20 to 30 millimetres are currently forecast. Flurries are expected to begin by Wednesday afternoon, as brisk westerly winds usher in colder temperatures. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:57:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:58:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1489925429.2019
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Storm moving into the region will bring significant rainfall today and continuing into Wednesday morning. Rain has begun across Nova Scotia and will continue tonight. Rainfall warnings have been issued for much of mainland Nova Scotia, except for Yarmouth, the Annapolis Valley region, and the Cobequid Peninsula. Rain will change to flurries over western Nova Scotia late tonight night as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Driving conditions may become difficult overnight or Wednesday morning as the cold air and flurries push eastward across the province. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:59:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T15:00:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3257818206.2019
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Yarmouth County, Cumberland County - Minas Shore, Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County - Cobequid Bay, Colchester County North, Richmond County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Arctic air remains entrenched in the central and northern interior as a frontal system brought in warm moist air aloft. These conditions may lead to patchy freezing rain mixed at times with ice pellets or snow this morning. The risk of freezing rain is forecast to end this afternoon as warm air reaches the surface and brings temperatures above the freezing mark. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T01:59:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T15:19:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3632561263.2019
Area: Bulkley Valley, McGregor
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for this afternoon and tonight. Lake effect snow bands are expected to intensify and will affect areas southeast of Georgian Bay beginning late this afternoon and will continue into Wednesday morning. Travel may be impacted due to accumulating snow, particularly during the afternoon commute. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected. Total rainfall: 50 to 80 mm Locations: southwestern Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to Grey River. Time span: today until midday on Wednesday. Remarks: After a brief period of snow this morning precipitation has changed over to rain, except along the Burgeo highway where the snow will persist until early this afternoon. Rain at times heavy is forecast to continue through tonight before tapering off Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:25:34-00:00

Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow will change to freezing rain this evening which will end overnight tonight. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Update:  Precautionary Drinking Water
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: Precautionary Drinking Water for the Unorganized Hamlet of Lac Vert. This advisory is for the Unorganized Hamlet of Lac Vert and for any individuals who may access water from the Lac Vert system. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Advisory has been extended until Friday Nov 15, 2019

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An additional 5 to 10 centimetres of snow is expected over these areas by this evening. Strong winds combined with snow will strongly reduce visibilities locally in blowing snow. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls possible this afternoon. Flurries and local snow squalls are expected to begin this afternoon and continue into Wednesday. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm per 12 hours are possible along with local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to southwest on Wednesday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm possible. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik. Time span: overnight tonight until Thursday morning. Remarks: The snow will be accompanied by strong north to northeasterly winds gusting up to 70 km/h on Wednesday giving reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will further increase from the north to northwest Wednesday night, with gusts of 100 to 130 km/h possible, causing blizzard like conditions. As a result, this watch is likely to be upgraded to a warning in subsequent forecasts later today. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:57:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:58:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1657656944.2019

Flurries and local snow squalls will continue to affect the area this morning and early this afternoon before moving out of the region in the late afternoon. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts: 5 to 15 cm, highest amounts inland. Locations: Cartwright and south to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: This afternoon through to Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will develop this afternoon along the Labrador Straits and spread northward, reaching Cartwright this evening. The snow will then transition to rain from south to north overnight into Wednesday morning with a period of freezing rain likely over inland areas. Highest snowfall accumulations are expected inland and over higher terrain, particularly along the Trans-Labrador Highway, where temperatures will be slower to rise. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:56:25-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected. Total rainfall: 35 to 55 mm. Locally higher amounts possible over higher terrain. Locations: Bay St. George up to the Bay of Islands Time span: this afternoon until early Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: After 5 to 10 cm snow today, precipitation is expected to transition to rain this afternoon. Warm temperatures and rain will combine to cause any existing snow pack to melt and may contribute to water pooling. Rain is forecast to continue through Tuesday night before transitioning to flurries Wednesday afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Southerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior are expected to produce flurries and local snow squalls on Wednesday. The squalls could start as early as Wednesday morning and are expected to continue through Wednesday night. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible on Wednesday, however areas closer to Lake Superior could see locally higher amounts of 15 to 25 cm. Additional amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities will also be a concern. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to the northwest on Thursday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T16:05:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2010809417.2019

Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Locations: Rigolet, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River. Time span: Tonight, Wednesday, and Wednesday night. Remarks: The heaviest snowfall is expected overnight and Wednesday morning. Snow will be accompanied with north to northeasterly winds gusting to 50 or 60 km/h, resulting in blowing snow over exposed areas. Over eastern areas of the Trans-Labrador Highway in the Eagle River forecast region, a period of freezing rain is expected Wednesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:52:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:53:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3343701938.2019
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: 100 to 120 km/h. Time span: today until early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds with gusts up to 120 km/h are expected today. Winds will diminish slightly tonight, but gusts between 80 to 100 km/h are still expected. Winds are forecast to diminish early Wednesday morning when they shift to westerly. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:22:39-00:00

Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Area on 2019-11-12. An intense low pressure system will generate strong northeasterly winds over the areas specified below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of mid-sized tidal range could produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near theses localities on Tuesday and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2019-11-12, from 12 PM to 4 PM. Matane: 2019-11-12, from 12 PM to 4 PM. Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2019-11-12, from 11:30 AM to 3:30 PM. Baie-Comeau: 2019-11-12, from 11:30 AM to 3:30 PM. Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier: 2019-11-12, from 11:30 AM to 0:30 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-12T23:59:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T16:43:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2757789992.2019
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 15 to 25 centimetres of snow is expected by this evening or tonight. The snow will be accompanied by strong winds which will reduce visibilities in blowing snow. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Storm moving into the region will bring significant rainfall today and tonight. Rain has begun across Nova Scotia and will continue into tonight. Total rainfall accumulations are expected to be quite variable, with forecast amounts ranging from 30 to 65 mm and locally higher amounts possible along parts of the Atlantic coast. Rain will change to flurries over western Nova Scotia overnight into Wednesday as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Driving conditions may become difficult overnight or Wednesday morning as the cold air and flurries push eastward across the province. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T07:00:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T15:01:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3186484669.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain or rain will change to periods of rain this afternoon. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions in areas of freezing rain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain to northwestern New Brunswick today. Snow will be heavy at times today, and is forecast to become mixed with ice pellets or freezing rain over portions of these regions except for Madawaska and Restigouche Counties, where precipitation is expected to remain as snow throughout the event. Precipitation is forecast to taper to scattered flurries this evening. Further snowfall amounts of near 25 cm are expected except only 5 cm for the Woodstock region. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions in snow and mixed precipitation. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:58:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:59:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3320786891.2019
